p.s: Both the Amish and Mennonites stem from similar cultural and religious heritages , making it tricky to distinguish between the two .
Luckily , there are several ways to figure out whether someone is Amish or a Mennonite without having to straightforwardly ask them .
By looking at their clothing or asking them questions about things like their education or religious meeting places , you 'll soon know whether they 're Amish or a Mennonite .

item.s: Find out if they ’re interested in higher education .
The Amish usually do n’t allow any type of higher education because they think it gets in the way of their faith .
However , Mennonites do accept higher education .
Ask the person if they ’re in school or getting a degree to find out if they ’re Amish or a Mennonite .
If they ’re young you might ask , “ Are you planning on going to college ? ”
Ask an older person a question like , “ Did you choose to earn a degree ? ” to see if they ’re Amish or a Mennonite .
Ask about their beliefs on going to college too , if desired .
Check whether they use technology or electricity .
Amish people do n’t use technology , and instead of using cars , they prefer to use horse-drawn carriages instead .
They also avoid using electricity .
Mennonites are more accepting of technology of all kinds , and they do use cars as well as electricity .
Asking or finding out if they drive cars or use electricity is an easy way to figure out if they ’re Amish or not .
Mennonites allow electricity and telephones in the home .
Some Amish groups may have one telephone that they use collectively .
Look at their clothing to figure out if they 're Amish or Mennonites .
Amish people tend to dress more conservatively in plain clothing , with women wearing dresses or head coverings .
Mennonites do n’t have a strict dress code and are often dressed like everyday people .
If you see people dressed very modestly , it ’s likely that they ’re Amish as opposed to Mennonites .
The Amish wear solid-colored clothing in blues , grays , whites , and blacks .
Men wear black suits and straw or felt hats , while the women wear dresses and prayer caps .
Find out how much they interact with the outside world .
The Amish are a tight knit community and tend not to get involved in everyday society .
Mennonites are close to the opposite — they 're well-integrated into modern society and have lots of involvement with other people .
Because the Amish are so isolated , their jobs often include agricultural work in their communities .
Mennonites live among regular communities and often have regular jobs as well .
Ask where they have their church services .
Mennonites have their church services in meeting houses while Amish people meet in smaller places like homes , barns , or shops .
By asking the person where they meet for church , you ’ll be able to figure out whether they ’re Amish or a Mennonite .
You could also ask them what language they use during the service — German or Pennsylvania Dutch is often used by the Amish , while English is primarily used by the Mennonites .
Use the size of their worship group to help you decide if they ’re Amish or Mennonites .
The Amish tend to worship in smaller groups because of space limitations — they ’re expected to host church services in their houses .
Mennonites worship in large meeting spaces , meaning their groups can get quite large .
While an Amish worship group might have 15-20 people in it , a Mennonite group could have 50-100 people .
Find out if they do missionary work or only stay in their communities .
Mennonites are known for their outreach in the community , going on missionary trips around the world to actively help others .
They use this as a way to spread their religious beliefs while assisting those in need .
The Amish do all of their charitable giving close to home and do n’t tend to stray from their community .
If you think someone might be a Mennonite , ask them if they do any missionary work to find out for sure .
Know that there are always exceptions , so ask several different types of questions to find out for sure whether the person is Amish or a Mennonite .
If all else fails , politely ask them .
It 's likely that they 'll be glad to tell you and happy that you 're interested in learning about their lifestyle .
